Award.AwardTitle: Prediction and Discovery of Host Metabolites and Metabolic Pathways Required for Proliferation of an Obligate Fungal Biotroph

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Powdery mildews are widespread fungal pathogens that cause major crop loss and susceptible crops are regularly treated to limit infection. Most people have observed the white powdery-like growth associated with powdery mildews in their gardens for example, on leaves of roses. Powdery mildews are obligate biotrophs, meaning they can only grow and reproduce on living plants. As such, they obtain all nutrients from the plant host. The goal of this project is to couple cutting edge approaches in molecular genetics and genomics, analytical chemistry, informatics and modeling to identify the specific plant metabolites required by the powdery mildew for its growth and reproduction. Broader impacts of this work include developing novel tools and resources for the study of powdery mildews and similar types of biotrophs for the research community, identifying novel targets to limit powdery mildew growth to enhance crop yield while limiting chemical treatments, and training and mentoring our next generation of scientists,including under-represented minority students, in cross-disciplinary science.

The powdery mildew-host plant system is uniquely suited to the development of tools and approaches that can be applied more generally for the study of inter-organismal metabolism and development. This project will iteratively create a constraint-based powdery mildew-host plant integrated metabolic metabolic model to predict host and fungal metabolic pathways. This will be accomplished by: i) developing novel computational and experimental platforms, tools, and approaches, ii) identifying critical metabolites and pathways required by obligate fungal biotrophs for their development and proliferation, and iii) determining nutritional requirements to enable axenic culturing. The project also seeks to obtain fundamental insights into nutrient reservoir metabolism as local plant cells are used to fuel the sustained growth and reproduction of the fungus, as well as knowledge about control points and pathways targeted by pathogens. The broader impacts include advancing knowledge of the powdery mildew - plant host interaction, training our next generation of cross-disciplinary STEM scientists through mentoring of students and postdocs, development, testing, and use of integrated metabolic databases and prediction tools for the broader scientific community, and identifying novel targets to limit powdery mildew growth and reproduction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Powdery mildews are widespread fungal pathogens that cause major crop loss. They are obligate biotrophs that obtain all nutrients from the plant host and are propagated on plants. Through the development and use of genome, global expression, and metabolic data, the uniquely skilled, cross-disciplinary, and collaborative team with PI Wildermuth at UC Berkeley (powdery mildew-host plant experimental system), Co-PI Rhee at the Carnegie Institution for Science (metabolic databases and network modeling), and Co-PI Northen at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (metabolomics) developed an integrated view of adapted powdery mildew-host metabolism.

 As part of this effort, a powdery mildew-plant host integrated metabolic network database was created, allowing for meta-network, constraints-based metabolic network modeling to predict infection phase-specific requirements of the powdery mildew from its host plant. Plant host metabolites and metabolic pathways required by powdery mildews for their proliferation were further explored through the use of plant mutants in specific genes and pathways identified as important to the powdery mildew. In parallel, through the development of spray-induced gene silencing of powdery mildew targets, powdery mildew genes involved in manipulating plant host metabolism and in growth and reproduction of the powdery mildew itself were ascertained.

This allowed for i) the identification of key shifts in plant metabolism to provide the powdery mildew with specific required metabolites and ii) the determination of powdery mildew genes encoding proteins that manipulate plant host metabolism or utilize plant metabolites to fuel fungal growth and reproduction.  In addition, systems for exometabolomic studies of plant-microbe interactions were developed for further application to the powdery mildew-plant host system.

The powdery mildew-host plant system is uniquely suited to the development of transformative platforms, tools and approaches that can be applied more generally for the study of inter-organismal metabolism and development. More specifically, obligate biotrophs often require similar metabolites from their host and use common strategies to colonize their host, manipulate the host for nutrient acquisition, and evade host defenses. This interdisciplinary project i) developed novel computational and experimental platforms, tools, and approaches, ii) identified critical metabolites and pathways required by obligate fungal biotrophs for their development and proliferation, and iii) determined nutritional requirements of the powdery mildew to facilitate future culturing of powdery mildews, in the absence of the plant host.

 

Broader Impacts

Powdery mildews are considered to have the most extensive economic impact of any pathogen on worldwide agronomic yield. Through this project, novel plant targets were identified that can be used to develop plants that are more resistant to powdery mildews. And, the methodology and targets for RNA-based fungicides that can be applied to plants to silence powdery mildew genes thereby reducing powdery mildew disease were determined. The genomes of obligate biotrophs including human pathogens have reduced gene content and typically have lost the same metabolic pathways; therefore, the project approaches and findings provides insights into other obligate biotroph-host interactions and their evolution.

This project trained and developed our next generation of cross-disciplinary STEM scientists through mentoring of numerous undergraduates, two graduate students, and three postdocs, including >50% women, first generation college-educated, and under-represented minority students. This included summer research experiences that broadened participation in scientific research.
